moves.1. d4: On Thursday evening, for the first time I went one-on-one against a grandmaster in a chess game! I was playing board 1 for Oswestry A and played Keith Arkell who was playing board 1 for Newport A.
moves.1... Nf6: Keith and his brother Nick arrived late. The match was due to start at 7.30pm. At the request of the Newport captain I delayed starting the clock until 7.45pm.
moves.2. Nf3: Perhaps as a consequence of this Keith rattled out his first moves.
moves.2... g6: I start to finachetto my bishop.
moves.4... d5: I turn it into a Grunfeld Defence.
moves.5... Nxd5: I take back. I was rather expecting him to turn it into a modern way of handling the exchange variation with 6. e2-4.
moves.6. g3: But he plays this, which was new to me.
moves.7... c5: The thematic attack on the centre.
moves.10. Be3: He wants to play Ne5 discovering an attack on my queen.
moves.10... c4: Although this reduces the pressure on the white centre, This is quite playable.
moves.11. Ne5: So he comes in with the discovered attack, as in Splosnov, Sergei (2367) vs. Votava, Jan (2505).
moves.11... Qb5: The queen needs to protect c4 and c6
moves.13. b3: Still following Splosnov, Sergei (2367) vs. Votava, Jan (2505).
moves.13... Be6: And this is what Jan Votava(2505) played too.
moves.14. Rc1: But here we depart company. Sergei Splosnov(2367) preferred b3xc4 immediately.
moves.14... Rac8: Although this move is not exactly bad, moving the a8 rook away from possible attack from Bg2 is a good idea, and so is protecting c6, as I am now threatening c4xb3, after the game Keith suggested Ra-d8 as being even stronger. Fritz likes Ra-b8 here.
moves.15. bxc4: Now that c6 is protected this is virtually forced, as I was threatening c4xb3.
moves.15... Bxc4: So I take back, threatening e2.
moves.16... Qa6: I drop back, keeping the pressure on e2.
moves.17... Rfd8: And I am happy with my position. Knights are exchanged, all my pieces are developed to reasonable squares. My c6 is weak, but it should not be terminal.
moves.18. Qc2: Attacking my bishop. Fritz puts white up at 0.15 - hardly anything.
moves.18... Bd5: I considered Be6 but it is even better to challenge his Bg2.
moves.19. Red1: He improves the position of his Re1.
moves.19... Bxg2: I take his powerful bishop off.
moves.21... Rcd8: Keith thought this move was a minor mistake. Fritz thinks it is best however. I thought I was getting rid of my weak pawn and leading to more exchanges. I was rather thinking I was getting near a drawable ending here.
moves.24. Rc7: This was the move I missed on move 21. I ws expecting exchanges on d4.
moves.24... Bxe3: We wondered afterwards if there were improvements on this move, but Fritz thinks it is best. Fritz gives white an advantage of plus 1 now.
moves.25. Rxe3: He takes back, attacking e7 and a7.
moves.25... Rd8d7: When I played my last move, I thought this defended both pawns. When I saw this position on the board, I saw what was coming...
moves.28... f5: This is probably a mistake. Fritz prefers Kg7. White's advantage goes up from plus 1 to plus 1.25 according to Fritz.
moves.30. g4: I think he wanted me to exchange, leaving him with a passed e pawn.
moves.30... Kf6: But I refuse. Fritz prefers taking, and gives white as only up 0.58.
moves.31... gxf5: I took this way - again to stop him from having a passed e pawn. Fritz prefers taking with the king and now gives white as up 1.01.
moves.33... Kh5: I played this to prevent any further advance of this pawn. Fritz prefers Kf6 and gives white as up 1.29 now.
moves.34. e3: I think this is a bit of a waiting move, quietly improving his position.
moves.38... a5: "Passed pawns must be pushed"! Fritz says white is up 1.19 now.
moves.39... Kg7: King drops back. Although he had started about 20 minutes behind me, I think I had used more time that him now, but neither of us were in any time trouble.
moves.40. Rc6: Rooks stops my king from advancing.
moves.40... Ra1: This seemed to me to be the natural move, but Fritz prefers Rb4 with an advantage of only 1.01 to white.
moves.41... Kh7: Forced, if I want to keep my h pawn.
moves.42. Ra6: He comes back behind my a pawn.
moves.43. Ra7+: Another check, driving my king back.
moves.44. Kf4: King comes up, avoiding being checked by my rook with Ra8-g8+
moves.45. Kf5: His king carries on advancing. Fritz gives white as up 2.58 now.
moves.45... a2: Keith wondered if this may be a mistake too, as it stops my rook marking time with R8-a7-a8 and also maybe playing Ra7 and exchanging the a pawn for his f pawn.
moves.46. Kf6: I think the game is lost now, and I will show you the final moves without further comments.
moves.46... Kh8 47. Ra4 Kh7 48. Ra8 Rh1 49. Rx: And black resigns. Keith said afterwards " You certainly did give a good account of yourself in our game. It could easily have been played between 2 GMs, or a GM and an IM, and were it on ''Chessbomb'', for example, there would be very few 'red' moves." Many thanks for reading. Please leave a comment or two and/or rate the annotation on the star system. Until next time dear reader!

players: Keith Arkell (ECF237) vs. Charles L Higgie (ECF180)
